Posts.Title: Happy

Posts.Content: Greeting brothers, Just retired in May and so me and the wife both now retired have been having some fun with the new time on our hands. To tell the truth I really didn't want to think about any prostate worries until it was testing time again which was coming up in November. Still going to MSK every 6 months. Happy to say I'm still a Zero Club member... for now anyway. To anyone new here reading this the info and opinions here on this forum are indispensable I think. Do your own research. use this forum as a place to help you get thru issues we all face and have faced with PCa. Best to all who arrive here. JD

Posts.Content: Thank you for responding. I f/u with the surgeons office. The PA said ...It is not unusual to see blood in the urine for several weeks following surgery and that I was correct that it is due to a scab coming off of the internal incision site. I should increase my fluid intake until I no longer see blood or little particles in my urine... I just needed conformation about what I was seeing as I was peeing.

Posts.Title: Is this to be expected?

Posts.Content: I also had a PCA 3 test done as part of my journey. The PCA3 test looks for the expression of genes found only in prostate cancer cells.Cells from the prostate are shed into the urine. That's why the DRE was done prior to the PCA 3 test.

Posts.Title: Update on Secondary Treatment

Posts.Content: Has anyone had an issue with their insurance company obtaining Viagra for whatever reason? Any appeals that have been made because company first denied the Rx? Did I miss a post on this already? Briefly, I'm trying to get my ducks in order now because I have decided to have surgery (with 2nd surgeon interviewed, he's done over 2000 DaVinci's) instead of Brachytherapy and Irreversible Electroporation. Instructions are to take Viagra prior to and after surgery as you know so I'm trying to get ahead a little now as surgery is scheduled for 10/21/2015. Hey big leap forward this week...THE DECISION... and I'm not looking back! Thanks all I love this site. JD
Posts.Title: Viagra insurance issues?

Posts.Title: I'm still in the Club!

Posts.Content: Hi ibero48, I went to Sloan and was very pleased with the team there. With my particular case I was a good candidate for several options. Brachytherapy (seeds); radiation; surgery or irreversible electroporation( that involves the use of small needles to deliver an electrical current to small, localized prostate tumors) Even though we are all affected by PCa everyone must make their own decision on how best to treat their particular case. In my opinion the best way to arrive at a decision is speak with your physician, read Patrick Walsh's Surviving Prostate Cancer lll edition and stay connected to this forum. If you want to speak with me send me a private post and I'd be happy to share what my experience was at MSK. I went with the "robot" for surgery.

Posts.Title: PCa diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Greeting brothers, Just retired in May and so me and the wife both now retired have been having some fun with the new time on our hands. To tell the truth I really didn't want to think about any prostate worries until it was testing time again which was coming up in November. Still going to MSK every 6 months. Happy to say I'm still a Zero Club member... for now anyway. To anyone new here reading this the info and opinions here on this forum are indispensable I think. Do your own research. use this forum as a place to help you get thru issues we all face and have faced with PCa. Best to all who arrive here. JD

Posts.Title: 15 Month followup

Posts.Content: Speaking of "neat" orgasms...first time last night a very neat one after 100mg Viagra (but little elvis starting standing prior to Viagra too) with the help of the little woman of the house, Whala!...4/5 of nice wood and a rousing big O...nothing from the Cowpers ... It's just been 4 weeks since surgery so that was really nice and to know that the feeling is still there and that the plumbing seems to be working OK. That coupled with continence during the day and night except a sneeze/cough might bring out a drop or two (and yeah a little bit of beer and I'm leaking a little too) , I'm not complaining...still have some specks of internal scab mixed in the urine...

Posts.Title: Cowper's Glands

Posts.Content: Best of luck, yr going to be surprised how soon you feel yrself , especially after the cath is out. No pain it's just a little cumbersome when getting around. Consider an electric recliner to help get up and down more easily than in and out of bed. It really made a difference for me. Keep in touch we're all in this together, brother
Posts.Title: Surgery Day Soon and Right Mind Set

Posts.Content: Hi I am jdsky's wife Linda. I want to take this opportunity to thank all of you for your support to my husband. He has been inspired and made to feel much more comfortable about his upcoming surgery due to your great comments and stories. I go on this site as well and read everything. I have learned so much. Well we will be leaving for Sloan Kettering on Tuesday and then the surgery is Wed. I think we are prepared with supplies, meds, etc. I may need your support as well as the caregiver looking for advice. Thanks again to a great group!!!

Posts.Title: 72 hours... Homina, Homina

Posts.Content: Well it's been sometime now waiting, reading, learning and directly speaking with fellow PCa brothers some right here from this forum and others...thanks guys . I'm about to really start the journey to the other side of this malady in about 72 hours from today. I'm actually pretty calm considering what's about to take place. After all the last operation I had was when I was 5 yo and got ether for anesthesia. So even though I am an RN and have worked in hospitals and healthcare facilities for many years I was always on the other side of the fence. It was always the other guy getting stuff done. I know I've done my due diligence and have prepared as much as possible and now it's time to be secure in the decisions I've made with my beautiful wife right by my side every step of the way. So wish me luck fellows and I'll be happy to discuss the outcomes when I'm up and "running" again.

Well we will be leaving for Sloan Kettering on Tuesday and then the surgery is Wed. I think we are prepared with supplies, meds, etc. I may need your support as well as the caregiver looking for advice. Thanks again to a great group!!!

Posts.Title: 72 hours... Homina, Homina

Posts.Content: Well it's been sometime now waiting, reading, learning and directly speaking with fellow PCa brothers some right here from this forum and others...thanks guys . I'm about to really start the journey to the other side of this malady in about 72 hours from today. I'm actually pretty calm considering what's about to take place. After all the last operation I had was when I was 5 yo and got ether for anesthesia. So even though I am an RN and have worked in hospitals and healthcare facilities for many years I was always on the other side of the fence. It was always the other guy getting stuff done. I know I've done my due diligence and have prepared as much as possible and now it's time to be secure in the decisions I've made with my beautiful wife right by my side every step of the way. So wish me luck fellows and I'll be happy to discuss the outcomes when I'm up and "running" again.

Any thoughts greatly appreciated The waiting is the hardest part. Thanks JD

Posts.Title: Am I waiting too long?

Posts.Content: Systematic review and meta-analysis published by BMJ September 5, 2018 https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.k3519 Conclusions At best, screening for prostate cancer leads to a small reduction in disease-specific mortality over 10 years but has does not affect overall mortality. Clinicians and patients considering PSA based screening need to weigh these benefits against the potential short and long term harms of screening, including complications from biopsies and subsequent treatment, as well as the risk of overdiagnosis and overtreatment After all is said and done I decided to be tested, weighed my options and took action never to look back.

Posts.Content: I'd never join a club that would have me as member but I will now. 63 yo; recent Dx of T1c; 3+4 gleason;had MRI-US guided Bx; I'm a good candidate for all of the above. I'm a patient @ MSK in NYC. the Surgeon I am working with has done 350 RP Davinci surgeries. The electroporation (only the "4" of the tumor is treated) is a pretty new technology and even though it is FDA approved there is still no long term studies done. The Surgeon said that's what he would choose but he likes to be on the cutting edge so to speak Not so crazy about the radiation route. Any suggestions would be helpful. Thanks.
Posts.Title: Irreversible Electroporation; surgery; radiation

Posts.Content: Thanks all for writing Yes Track Record makes sense. Like Dr Patrick Walsh says : even if a new tx was found today it would take 10-15 yrs to see if it worked. The IE just does the spot shown on the MRI-US. Then at 6 months another MRI-US Bx is done and repeat tx can be done if something else is found or surgery or radiation at any point. Not all that adventurous and really not too interested in being a pioneer, however with the IE treatment all options remain on the table. Of course I don't like the idea that if in 6 months after tx the Bx shows another spot so then Im still dealing with the PCa. Yes I don't know if 350 RPs are enough to get out of the learning curve...Dr Walsh says more than 300 is a good answer. What do I tell the surgeon about changing to someone else with more surgeries under his belt? My surgeon is at MSK so that says something about his skill I think. But. How does one find the percentage of successful surgeries a surgeon has done? Thanks a lot for all the info

Posts.Title: HAPPY thanksgiving - Lots to be Thankful For

Posts.Content: Well said all . Yes a lot to be thankful for , I was thankful just to make it out of surgery and still be me . Thankful for good pathology result, next is first post surgery PSA result . This forum and the posters have been so very helpful I can't even begin to thank everyone but this place has made a huge difference for me And my wife to get us thru the decisions and the whole ordeal of Pca up to this point. I always endeavor to give back with info and support to the posters the best I can and would encourage anyone to feel free to send a private post that I'd be more than happy to share my experience up to this point. So a very happy healthy Thanksgiving to all

Posts.Title: HAPPY thanksgiving - Lots to be Thankful For

Posts.Content: Where are you getting your Viagra/Cialis from? I had to battle the old insurance company with a letter from MSK but was finally approved for 30 pills x 3 refills. I recently had to change insurance companies and the battle is about to start to get Viagra again. New company is BC/BS. If I was having trouble getting Viagra from BC/BS I was referred by MSK to inquire Jan Drugs in Canada. However there is a FDA warning that appears that states this drug store is a "rouge pharmacy" Definition of a Rogue Internet Pharmacy An Internet pharmacy is rogue if it qualifies as unapproved, and: The sale, prescribing or dispensing of prescription or other drugs reasonably appears to intentionally or knowingly violate, facilitate the violation of, or offer to facilitate the violation of applicable laws or regulations, defined as the laws and regulations where the drugs are dispensed from or where they are offered to be shipped to; Does not adhere to accepted standards of medical and/or pharmacy practice, including standards of safety; and/or Engages in fraudulent or deceptive business practices Anybody have any experience or any follow up tips for getting Viagra?

Posts.Title: a simple thanks

Posts.Content: I'm good ...for now. First PSA post op < 0.05 At MSK the phlebotomist said I should have the results in about 4 hours which I've gotten results before in that time frame. Blood drawn @ 1130 am . So here it is 1130 pm and still nothing . Did they lose the sample, tube break ...??? You know? Really upset. Finally at 4am this morning got the news .
Posts.Title: First post op PSA

Posts.Content: Today wife and me heading to NYC to MSK for first post op PSA exactly 3 months to the day of surgery . I can report that incontinence not really a problem just a small drip if getting up quickly or sneezing or coughing unexpectedly. Dry otherwise . It does take a while to get erection but I'm about 80% of per surgery firmness . Today I'm hoping for admission into the Zero Club with a good PSA result. MSK has blood test results within hours so I'm hanging on.
